perturbation.original_text: Licensee agrees to reasonably cooperate with Licensor in achieving registration of the Licensed Mark worldwide, and in maintaining and protecting existing registrations therefor at Licensor's sole expense. Licensee shall execute any and all documents which Licensor may reasonably request in support of such registrations, and, at Licensor's request, Licensee shall provide use evidence, testimony, and documentation that may be required in any ex parte or inter partes administrative proceedings and prosecutions, maintenance and renewals involving registrations of the Licensed Mark, at Licensee's sole expense.
perturbation.changed_text: Licensee will consider cooperating with Licensor in the registration of the Licensed Mark worldwide, and in maintaining and protecting existing registrations. Licensee may execute documents which Licensor requests in support of such registrations, and Licensee may provide use evidence, testimony, and documentation that may be required in administrative proceedings related to registrations of the Licensed Mark.
perturbation.explanation: Changing 'agrees to reasonably cooperate' to 'will consider cooperating' makes the obligation to cooperate optional and vague. Changing 'shall execute' to 'may execute' and 'shall provide' to 'may provide' further weakens the mandatory nature of the Licensee's assistance. This introduces ambiguity about the extent of the Licensee's commitment, making enforcement difficult.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Trademark Law - Lanham Act, which requires reasonable cooperation in protecting trademark rights to avoid dilution and abandonment claims.

perturbation.original_text: Licensor, as owner of the Licensed Mark, shall have the right at all times to control and approve the nature and quality of the Licensed Products (and the Licensed Mark thereon), and to inspect Licensee's business operations upon reasonable prior notice for the purpose of ensuring that a high level of quality of the Licensed Products is being maintained by Licensee. At Licensor's reasonable request during each calendar year, Licensee shall submit samples to Licensor, at no cost to Licensor, and shall not materially depart therefrom without Licensor's prior express written consent.
perturbation.changed_text: Licensor, as owner of the Licensed Mark, may, at its discretion, offer suggestions regarding the nature and quality of the Licensed Products, and may request to inspect Licensee's business operations following notification. At Licensor's request, when deemed appropriate, Licensee should consider submitting samples to Licensor, and may depart from previous quality standards if it deems necessary.
perturbation.explanation: Changing 'shall have the right at all times to control and approve' to 'may, at its discretion, offer suggestions' weakens the Licensor's control over quality. Replacing 'shall submit samples' with 'should consider submitting samples' and 'shall not materially depart therefrom without Licensor's prior express written consent' with 'may depart from previous quality standards if it deems necessary' makes quality control discretionary and vague. This undermines the Licensor's ability to maintain brand integrity.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Trademark Law - Lanham Act, which requires trademark owners to exercise sufficient control over licensees to prevent consumer deception and maintain the quality associated with the trademark. Failure to do so can lead to abandonment of the trademark.

perturbation.original_text: Licensee agrees to comply with Licensor's trademark usage guidelines and any other policies and requirements applicable to the Licensed Mark.
perturbation.changed_text: Licensee agrees to consider Licensor's trademark usage guidelines and may attempt to adhere to other policies and requirements applicable to the Licensed Mark.
perturbation.explanation: Replacing 'agrees to comply' with 'agrees to consider' and 'any other policies and requirements' to 'may attempt to adhere' introduces ambiguity. Compliance with guidelines becomes optional rather than mandatory. This is ambiguous since the Licensee is not obligated to take action.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Trademark Law - Lanham Act: If the licensee isn't required to comply, this can cause issues when defending marks, and lead to possible abandonment.
